1. Microkernel architecture: HURD is based on a microkernel architecture, where most of the operating system functionality is implemented as a set of servers that communicate with each other.

2. Device abstraction: HURD provides a device abstraction layer that allows device drivers to be written independently of the underlying hardware.

3. File system access: HURD allows users to access remote file systems by mounting them as local file systems, without requiring any special network protocols or tools.

4. Multi-server environment: HURD is designed to run multiple servers at the same time, each handling a particular part of the operating system functionality.

5. User-level networking: HURD allows networking to be implemented at the user-level, rather than the kernel-level, which provides more flexibility and modularity.

6. Integrated translator mechanism: HURD has an integrated translator mechanism that allows users to access different file systems and networks with the same syntax.

7. Extensible system call interface: HURD allows adding new system calls to the kernel dynamically, without requiring a kernel recompilation, which makes it easier to extend the operating system functionality.

8. User-level file system implementation: HURD allows for user-level file systems to be implemented, which provides more flexibility and easier development for new file systems.
